Award.AwardTitle: PECASE: Dielectric Phenotyping of Bacteria for Energy and Medicine

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
1150615-Buie, Cullen R.

The objective of the proposed research is to illuminate the coupling between cell envelope phenotype and dielectric properties. This will be achieved by the investigation of pathogenic bacteria and electrochemically active bacteria. A three-dimensional insulator based dielectrophoresis (3DiDEP) device will be used. The novel 3DiDEP platform enables non-invasive sorting, trapping, and characterization of living cells based upon the cell envelope phenotype. The hypothesis of the work is that 3DiDEP can be used to characterize the functions expressed on the bacteria cell envelope. 3DiDEP enables low voltage, high sensitivity separation and analysis of cells. Also, the proposed 3DiDEP employs electrodes outside of the microchannel, the technique operates at low frequency or DC electric fields.

The proposed 3DiDEP is a powerful technique for high throughput phenotyping in microbiology. Phenotype based selection using 3DiDEP represents one of the first applications of microfluidics in the growing field of phenomics. The proposed project may also help to address widespread concerns in diverse fields ranging from renewable energy to healthcare. The PI also proposes to develop relationships with target universitis to increase the representation of underrepresented minorities in MIT graduate programs. The PI has outlined a unique approach to train a new generation of underrepresented minority scientists who may return to their respective undergraduate institutions as faculty, thereby attacking the diversity issue on both the student and faculty levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project the principal investigator and his students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology developed and refined a technology to probe the electrical properties of bacterial cells. Bacteria are small, roughly 1/100th the width of a human hair, so most techniques to probe their properties are expensive and labor intensive. In this work, the team utilized a process known as insulator based dielectrophoresis in order to measure the electrical properties of bacterial cell surfaces. Bacteria are single celled organisms so they must use their surfaces to modulate interactions with the outside world. As a result, the bacterial cell surface is rich with information about the properties of the organism. The team at MIT developed a high sensitivity dielectrophoresis platform to measure these properties at low cost. The technique has been demonstrated in two specific cases thus far. First, they have been able to show that this dielectrophoresis platform can be used to distinguish bacteria based upon their ability to form biofilms. Biofilms are important physical structures formed by infection causing bacteria and dielectrophoresis provides an easy tool to detect biofilm forming bacteria within a sample. Second, the team has shown that dielectrophoresis can be used to measure the ability for electrical charges to re-organize themselves on a bacterial surface. It turns out that this property is closes related to a bacterial cells ability to conduct electrons to an electrode in a microbial fuel cell. Microbial fuel cells use special electrochemically active bacteria to convert the chemical energy in low value streams such as wastewater into useful electrical energy. Therefore, this dielectrophoresis technique coupled with genetic engineering or directed evolution can help to engineer special electrochemically active bacteria that can be used in microbial fuel cells to convert waste streams into electricity.

 

In addition to the research carried out in conjunction with this award, the PI has been highly active within the local and national engineering community. In 2016 the PI led and organized an international conference, held at MIT, devoted to the theory and practice of dielectrophoresis. This project brought together students and faculty from over a dozen countries to talk about the state of the art in dielectrophoresis research. Further, over the course of the award, the PI mentored multiple undergraduate students from underrepresented backgrounds within his laboratory and encouraged them to attend graduate school. This mentoring occurred under the auspices of formal research projects administered through the PIs lab or the MIT Summer Research Program. Lastly, in 2016 the PI organized a conference, in conjunction with the National Society of Black Engineers, to promote academic careers amongst underrepresented groups within engineering disciplines. These activities were devised to bolster the talent pool of engineers in the U.S. by increasing exposure of underrepresented students to research and related careers.
